												I just played the trilogy recently.  The 3rd one has problems.-They changed the control scheme on it.  ...Probably for the better, but still.-The Eagle doesn't feel quite as powerful in it as it did in the previous ones.  ...Which is again is probably for the better, since you basically never have to swap out the Eagle until late game in them.-The time limit maxes out at 4 minutes.  And not just "maxes out the display" and keeps rolling, but actually taps out at 4 minutes.  THIS is my biggest complaint with it.  You are basically forced to keep going in it, you never get a chance to really sit back and explore.  I like exploring the levels.  Pedestrians also give you almost no time.-The missions.  They were every other level here, not every 4th level like in the previous game.  They also... I dunno, mostly were uninspired?  They're not bad, but they seemed to be fairly bland, particularly early on.  They are hit and miss overall.Two other issues:  This game includes the Nosebleed Pack.  Now, it's nice in that "more cars, more maps, more content!"  However, these vehicles are not well balanced, and are available from the beginning.  And are available in the opponent's pool from the beginning.  And the hovering car can be very, very annoying to deal with.Another issue is that the game crashes on story missions.  This is a known issue.  There is a workaround.  The workaround is to turn off the mip filter.  HOWEVER, due to another glitch, that being badly coded menus where the content doesn't contain itself to the windows, you can't actually turn off the mip filter in game.You CAN do it from the setup though.  So open the setup, go to options, video, advance, and where you see "Mip filter", set it to none.  You may also need to disable Pixel Fog (though I didn't need to).  This should fix the problem.There's a lot to like about the third game though.  The graphics are a big step up.  The final levels in this game really look fantastic.  The story IS there, even if it's annoying at times.My favorite of the bunch is the second.  The third has problems.  So, why am I giving this a "yes" recommendation, despite all the flaws, including crashes?  Because, at the end of the day, it's still Carmageddon.  And if you need to get your fix, there ya go.

												Carmageddon TDR 2000 is a fun game,once you become acustomed to its idiosynchrocies.  Most modern computers experience a glitch caused by an antiquated Mip map and vertex fog better handled by Voodoo Rush and TNT Riva cards of yesteryear.  The fix is simple: backup your game cache through Steam first. browse Local Files, Open GFX file with Word Pad. Scroll to line 74 and edit line which reads all twos. Change last two to a zero, Save and done. The game has 25 races and 25 missions. For help with missions check out ZodApe's YewTewb Channel. I have seen complaints on here about the game is broken,too hard,not enough time etc.  Yet i imagine these same complainers plow happily throught the latest NFS broken crap because the Dice Team made it and they made Call of Droopy Diaties. Blow that!  Need more money to buy that sweet Hotty? Try racing the first level in The 20's and for the love of Pete,mow down every ped on the sidewalks. Keep  those Combo Multiplies spinning and you will make serious bank ~ $250K - $600K per play through.  Race it over and over until you have serious ends. Also the Train Station generously has Armor,Power and Slots All Around so you need not buy those,merely fill them for more even more nefarious power. Do You need more time? Use a bigger and slower car to hammer the competition. The "Jaws" car is a personal fave. Most Opponent Wasteds yield an extra minute and sometimes more added game play time.  Is this game for everyone? Hell no! You have to work hard to succeed. Without some skin in the game there can be no reward. This is a game from fifteen years  past when games were brutal but satisfying because you felt like you had accomplished something. if it is too hard then maybe Mario Kart or one of it's Brawzillion spinoffs is a better bet for you. Thanks for reading,be safe,keep well and happy gaming Playa.

SHORT VERSIONExpect:Frustrating missions, timer from hell, annoying cops, invisible barriers, PHYSICS!, tiny locales, OP car v car damage, tedious APO system, lots of cars (which you can't afford), accessibility ramps, computers on the roof, mutants, rampant jaywalking, lots of jumping over wallsDo Not Expect:Any feeling of accomplishment, to be able to win by killing all peds, um.. er.. PHYSICS!, a fair fight, an epic boss battle, any variety (despite appearances), a good story, humerous situations to share with friends, friends.LONG VERSIONIt was so tempting to give this game my reccomendation. I played it an awful lot when I was younger, and not knowing a lot else about Carmageddon at the time I really liked this game. Coming back to it after all these years I got to thinking that maybe I should have left the nostalgia as just that, but I craved the sense of fun this used to give me and I just couldn't see where I got it from.First of all, the game isn't terrible. Running people over and smashing into other cars is still largely taboo in driving games and so is still quite fun to do. It's the execution that lets this title down. The races are the standard Carma Kill all peds, kill all opponents or just finish the allotted number of laps, but it's not that simple. In TDR2000 the timer is most certainly NOT your friend. Want to hunt peds? Forget it. They take forever to kill and only yield a +2 second bonus which hardly offsets the 10+ seconds it took to finish them off in the first place. Want to waste everyone? Fine, but expect them to forget you exist half way through fighting (or in some cases, they don't even want to acknowledge you EVER existed at all.) Just want to race? HAH! Chasing checkpoints will run the clock down by the second lap.The truth of the matter is, in the races you APPEAR to be given the choice of how to complete them, but they always pan out in exactly the same way because you are constantly chronologically challenged and you pretty much have to waste at least one opponent to stand a chance of completing the event in ANY of the three possible ways.What else is on offer, you ask?  Well luckily if uniform race completion isn't for you then there are "missions". Missions like in GTA? Well... No. Sure you kill some people and race around trashing cars, but since you cannot actually LEAVE your vehicle, everything has to be possible to do whislt driving one. How do you access a computer? Why, just smash into the oversized console, of course! Need to destroy a mainframe? Well now, it's just sitting on the roof waiting to get trashed. Yes, THE ROOF. Somebody thought "You know, the ROOF is a great place for this computer that controls base security. Not like somebody is going to ramp up there and knock it off... or it RAINS." The placement of objectives that aren't just "gang leaders" to waste make you feel like you are using accessability ramps to get everywhere, like somebody thought "What if a CAR wanted to get into this office? Did we set up the keyboard to show detailed secure files when a car drives into it?". When the missions aren't being rediculous, they are being immensely frustrating and tedious. I understand that there is only so much you can do from the cockpit of a car beyond smashing into consoles or interfacing with rooftop computers, but there is very little variation beyond that. You end up wasting someone, collecting pieces of something scattered across the map, smashing peds or doing some crazy stunts to get to some unexplained point on a rooftop that defies reasonable explanation. PHYSICS. So much physics, it's just a shame that most of it is wrong, so very wrong. Invisible barriers. Yes, they are here, and they will wreck your ride and fail you some missions, because why not? If you're not getting beached on your own bodywork, you can bet you'll be getting beached on just about everything else. Vehicular weapons are great too, and in all fairness they do help, but wave goodbye to them as the slightest knock will detach them and any other piece of bodywork you hold dear, because in the TDR 2000 universe cars are not made of metal, precision welded and fastened to provide a sturdy shell for your car, no. Everything is held together with biscuits. Hit a bump in the road, and BAM those biscuits crumble and most of your bodywork is sailing away from you. Why am I complaining about this? Well, metal tends to deform when hit. It dents, it scratches, it tarnishes, it doesn't just fall away. Hell, it doesn't just fall away and then orbit you for about a hundred meters, pulling your car around and making it impossile to drive (I'm looking at you, "The Vulture"). There are times when the physics do good. Drive your car fast enough into another car and/or crush it between two objects and it will bend, or sometimes, very appealingly, split in half entirely. Rare, but very satisfying when you use your afterburner to turn your car into a high-velocity wrecking ball.Speaking of wrecking, a note on the APO (yes, it's back and more irrelevent than ever.) Upgrading your armour, power and offence seems like a great idea, until you realise you are just as slow as you were when you started, you are just as easy to waste and you are just as overpowered when ramming opponents/cops but you have NO MONEY LEFT. Seriously, save it for the cars, find one you like, they're all essentially the same except for King Merc (Much fun) and The Wheel (for when you want to spin around pointlessly unable to go in a straight line.) Go nuts. It really doesn't make a difference.Such destruction does often catch the attention of the police, but they are little more than a nuisance. Wasting them often proves easier than wasting some of your opponents, and they have no special weapons or abilities to make you think "Oh, damn. The police. Better avoid them!"I can't leave this review as it is without at least touching upon the humour. Carmageddon is supposed to be about all-out crude crazy chaotic nonesense, and TDR 2000 has none of it. I realise this particular installment wasn't developed by the original team, but boy does it show. The pre-mission "Cut-scene" dialogues aren't even funny (even though they are begging to be) and the power-ups/stunt/collision one-liners are pale in comparision to what the original developers drenched the other installments in.Just wait 'til it's cheap. If you didn't get it free, that is.

												Well lets start with a little backstory, imagine me about a decade ago, a teenager pining for the glory days of the original Carmageddon, where peds equal points and racing is for wimps, when lo and behold I found it.  A budget re-release copy of Carmageddon TDR2000, and at less than a fiver! I bought it instantly.  Maybe the fact that it's already a re-release title after a couple of years on the shelves should've had alarm bells ringing in my ears, but I bought it nonetheless, and after playing the first batch of races and missions I realised that this isn't the franchise I know and love, and by about halfway through I was bored and fed up with this game. After I completed it, I never touched it again.So what made this such a terrible gaming experience?  Lets start with the environments. At best they're mediocre, and the locations at least are as varied as the original game, but they also looked more dreary and washed out, and to be honest, rather uninspired. Also, althogh the game engine itself is fairly solid, I've got stuck on the level geometry enough times for it to be annoying.  As for the pedestrians that inhabit the maps, they would be satisfying to run over if they didn't all have adamantine skeletons.  I swear, unless you are going full pelt at them, you have to reverse back over them at least once in order to kill them (and even then it wasn't a guarantee!) If that wasn't bad enough the game only gives you a pittance of a time bonus for running them over. 2 seconds?! It took about that long to kill them in the first place!!!And the missions, oh god the missions!  Having one or two to break up the game is fine, but there were missions shoe-horned between every ♥♥♥♥ing race!  I just wanted to cause some carnage.  And if they weren't asinine fetch quests, they were convoluted and tedious, like shooting sharks with a slaughter mortar, which on paper sounds zany and fun, but in a vehicle can be awkward and frustrating to pull off.Then there are the cars themselves, all the rest might have been forgiven if the cars themselves were fun to drive, but they aren't.  They're ♥♥♥♥.  That in itself is a cardinal sin in ANY driving sim, let alone a Carmageddon sequel.To begin with, the line-up looks like an A-Z from a Poundland toys catalogue, Rangeing from the silly to the uninspired, with things like a motorized wooden hamster wheel, a pallid attempt at a steampunk monster truck, (which looks more like a boiler mounted on a horse cart,) a tank, nothing special, just a tank, and even a man driving a bathtub (really?), none of which fits the game's setting, bar one, Max's own Eagle, which you started with. Then there are those cars which goes beyond uninspired to just plain lazy: one of the cars is literally called "Sports Sedan", and is just that.  I watched a video of this game about a month ago and I couldn't tell the opponent vehicles from the rest of the traffic milling about on the map.  Needless to say you won't be tempted to drive every vehicle in the game.As for the handling it's okay for the most part, but a few vehicles refuse to turn from a standing start, some spin out like they have greased tyres, and then theres the novelty vehicles like the hovercar which is almost impossible to control and ends up adding nothing to the table in terms of gameplay.  I could go on about the gripes I have with the cars in this game (the damage modelling, the sounds, the physics...) but those are the biggest and as far as I'm concerned the worst.Now for the upshot.  Is it worth shelling out for this game? My advice is no.  There are better games (and sequels) out there that are worth paying for.  But what if despite its glaring flaws you still have fond, nostalgic memories from when you first played it, and want to experience it again. My advice is still no.  You can get this game and its two prequels for FREE if you buy Carmageddon: Reincarnation, which in my opinion is a far better investment, especially considering how well Reincarnation itself is already panning out.Sorry for the wall of text there, (it seemed shorter in my head) but tl;dr: Don't buy this game.

												This is my very first Steam review, as I feel the need to do this game justice. I play Carmageddon games since the demo of Carma 1 came out, all the way to TDR 2000, and still own the box versions. And of course I finished TDR 2000 many times and played it for dozens of hours, before Steam was even invented. This is the most hated Carmageddon game out there, even after the dissaster called Carmageddon: Reincarnation. But I never saw a real reason behind that, so I recommend this game to anyone who liked Carma 1 and 2, it's a decent game all around. Pros:+ Everything you might want from a Carma game is there+ Funny missions (much better than in Carma 2)+ Nice looking graphics that aged well+ The single player campaign is quite long and challengingCons:- too much missions for some- compatibility problems- less time in racesAbout the game:As a follow up to Carma 2, TDR adds even more missions, now after every race there is a mission. Some people never liked missions in Carma to begin with, but missions in TDR make much more sense than in Carma 2, have an actual story behind them, and some are quite hillarious. There is plenty of cars in TDR, but all of them are new, not a sinle good ol' ride from Carma 1&2. The new cars are good looking and most are fun to drive, but most people me included miss the old cars. All of the maps have a bit "post-apo" feeling to them which not everyone likes, but they are big enough and vary a lot.The visuals are a matter of taste, but I always loved the graphic. It is much more vivid and colorful game to look at that both it's predecessors. And in my opinion it stood the test of time very well.About compatibility I can only say that while I had some problems initially, now the game runs on Windows 7 absolutely without any problems.Carmageddon races always were time limited and you have to collect time by "various carmageddon means". In TDR the time you can collect is capped at 4 mins and you get a lot less time for everything, especially at higher difficulties. This makes the races more challenging, but it's a bit shame since you have a lot less time to explore the maps. This was probably the biggest issues I had with the game, but you can get used to it. My verdict is while Carmageddon 1&2 are better games overall, TDR 2000 is a good game that I would recommend to everyone who is interested in Carmageddon games. Why Stainless hates this game:All SCI ex-carma developers, headed by Noby, trash talk this game every time the have a chance. Why? Because they did not get to develop this game, and that's it. I don't know the story behind why this game was handed to Torus to develop instead of SCI, but Torus did a good job and I what Noby&rest are saying about them is just a disgusting slander. Would they made a better 3rd Carma game back then? Maybe, we'll never know. But after they made the excrement called Reincarnation, and then run away with our money, they don't get to say anything.
